contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox minister office | border = provincial | minister = prime | title = Premier | jurisdiction = Alberta | logo = Government of Alberta Logo.svg | logo_description = Logo of the Government of Alberta | image = Alison Redford 2012.jpg | incumbent = [[Alison Redford]] | his/her = His | appointed_by = [[Don Ethell]] | governor = [[Lieutenant Governor of Alberta]] | first_minister = [[Alexander Cameron Rutherford]] | date = September 2, 1905 }} The '''Premier of Alberta''' is the [[first minister]] for the [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Provinces of Canada|province]] of [[Alberta]]. He or she is the province's [[head of government]] and ''de facto'' chief executive. The current Premier of Alberta is [[Alison Redford]]. She became Premier by winning the [[Progressive Conservative Association of Alberta|Progressive Conservative]] leadership elections on October 2, 2011. Redford replaced [[Ed Stelmach]], who retired after serving as Premier for over four years. The Premier of the province deals with specific areas relating to Alberta and Alberta's relation on the national scene. The Premier acts as a representative for the [[Legislative Assembly of Alberta]] and the [[Members of the Legislative Assembly]] (MLA) are in turn the representatives of the people of Alberta. The Premier also acts as the MLA for a [[Electoral district (Canada)|riding]], and are elected as the MLA by the constituents of that particular riding. As with most government leaders in a [[parliamentary system]], the Premier usually wins his or her riding's election quite easily. However, some Premiers have not won their seat, forcing them to run in a by-election in another riding. The most recent case of this was [[Don Getty]], who lost his [[Edmonton-Whitemud]] seat in the [[Alberta general election, 1989|1989 election]] and had to run in [[Drumheller-Stettler]]. The Premier of Alberta's responsibilities include administering provincial [[laws]], enacting [[legislation]], and regulating industry.
